editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nayoon Ahn

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The changeling: as it was acted (With great applause) at the private house in Drury-lane, and Salisbury court.
Written by Thomas Midleton, and William Rowley. Gent '.
London, printed for Humphrey Moseley, and are to be sold at his shop at the sign of the princes-arms in st. Paul's churchyard, 1653.

list.head: Dramatis personae.
list.label: Vermandero,
Tomazo de Piracquo,
Alonzo de Piracquo,
Alsemero,
list.item: A nobleman, afterwards married to Beatrice.
list.label: Jasperino,
Alibius,
Lollio,
Pedro,
Antonio,
Franciscus,
Deflores,
Beatrice,
Diaphanta,
Isabella

div.head: Actus primus.
div.l: 'Twas in the temple where I first beheld her,
And now again the same, what omen yet
Follows of that? None but imaginary,
Why should my hopes or fate be timorous?
The place is holy, so is my intent:
I love her beauties to the holy purpose,
With man's first creation, the place blessed
And is his right home back (If he achieve it.)
The church hath first begun our interview
And that's the place must join us into one,
So there's beginning and perfection too.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.l: O sir, are you here? Come, the wind's fair with you,
You're like to have a swift and pleasant passage.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Sure you're deceived friend, 'tis contrary
In my best judgement.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: What for Malta?
If you could buy a gale amongst the witches,
They could not serve you such a lucky pennyworth
as comes a god's name.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Even now I observed
The temples vane to turn full in my face,
I know 'tis against me.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: Against you?
Then you know not where you are.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Not well indeed

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: Are you not well sir?

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Yes, Jasperino.
Unless there be some hidden malady
Within me, that I understand not.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: And that
I begin to doubt sir, I never knew
Your inclinations to travels at a pause
With any cause to hinder it till now.
Ashore you were wont to call your servants up,
And help to trap your horses for the speed.
At sea I have seen you weigh the anchor with 'em,
Hoist sails for fear to lose the foremost breath,
Be in continual prayers for fair winds,
And have you changed your orisons?

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: No, friend,
I keep 〈◊〉 same church, same devotion.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: Lover I'm sure you're none, the Stoic
Was found in you long ago, your mother
Nor best friends, who have set snares of beauty,
I and choice ones too, could never trap you that way
What might be the cause?

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Lord, how violent,
Thou art; I was but meditating of
Somewhat I heard within the temple.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: Is this violence? 'tis but idleness
Compared with your haste yesterday.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: I'm all this while a going, man.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: Backwards, I think, sir. Look your servants.

sp.speaker: 1 serv.
sp.l: The seamen call, shall we board your trunks?

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: No, not today.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: 'Tis the critical day,
It seems, and the sign in Aquarius.

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.l: We must not to sea today, this smoke will bring forth fire.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Keep all on shore, I do not know the end
(Which needs I must do) of an affair in hand
Ere I can go to sea.

sp.speaker: 1 serv.
sp.l: Well, your pleasure.

sp.speaker: 2 servant
sp.l: Let him e'en take his leisure too, we are safer on land.

div.stage: Enter Beatrice, Diaphanta, and servants, Joannna.

sp.speaker: Jasp.
sp.p: How now! The laws of the Medes are changed sure, salute a woman, he kisses too: wonderful! where learned he this? And does it perfectly too; in my conscience he ne'er rehearsed it before. Nay, go on, this will be stranger and better news at Valentia, then if he had ransomed half Greece from the Turk.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: You are a scholar, sir.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: A weak one, lady.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Which of the sciences is this love you speak of?

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: From your tongue I take it to be music.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: You are skilful in't, can sing at first sight.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: And I have showed you all my skill at once.
I want more words to express me further.
And must be forced to repetition:
I love you dear.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Be better advised, sir:
Our eyes are sentinels unto our judgements,
And should give certain judgement what they see;
But they are rash sometimes, and tell us wonders
Of common things, which when our judgements find,
They can then check the eyes, and call them blind.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: But I am further, lady; yesterday
Was mine eye's employment, and hither now
They brought my judgement, where are both agreed.
Both houses then consenting, 'tis agreed,
Only there wants the confirmation
By the hand royal, that's your part, lady.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: O there's one above me, sir, for five days past
To be recalled; sure, mine eyes were mistaken,
This was the man was meant me, that he should come
So near his time, and miss it.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.p: We might have come by the carriers from Valentia, I see and saved all our sea-provision: we are at farthest sure, methinks I should do something too, I meant to be a venturer in this voyage. Yonder's another vessel, I'll board her, if she be lawful prize, down goes her topsail.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Lady, your father.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Is in health, I hope.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Your eye shall instantly instruct you, lady.
He's coming hitherward.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: What needed then
Your duteous preface? I had rather
He had come unexpected, you must stall
A good presence with unnecessary blabbing:
And how welcome for your part you are,
I'm sure you know.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Wilt never mend this scorn
One side nor other? Must I be enjoined
To follow still whilst she flies from me? Well,
Fates do your worst, I'll please myself with sight
Of her, at all opportunities,
If but to spite her anger, I know she had
Rather see me dead then living, and yet
She knows no cause for't, but a peevish will.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: You seemed displeased lady on the sudden.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Your pardon sir, 'tis my infirmity,
Nor can I other reason render you,
Then his or hers, or some particular thing
They must abandon as a deadly poison,
Which to a thousand other tastes were wholesome,
Such to mine eyes is that same fellow there,
The same that report speaks of the basilisk.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: This is a frequent frailty in our nature,
There's scarce a man amongst a thousand sound,
But hath his imperfection: one distastes
The scent of roses, which to infinites
Most pleasing is, and odoriferous.
One oil, the enemy of poison,
Another wine, the cheerer of the heart,
And lively refresher of the countenance.
Indeed this fault (If so it be) is general,
There's scarce a thing but is both loved and loathed,
Myself (I must confess) have the same frailty.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: And what may be your poison sir? I am bold with you.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: And what might be your desire perhaps, a cherry.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I am no enemy to any creature
My memory has, but yon gentleman.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: He does ill to tempt your sight, if he knew it.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: He cannot be ignorant of that sir,
I have not spared to tell him so, and I want
To help myself, since he's a gentleman
In good respect with my father, and follows him.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: He's out of his place then now.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: I am a mad wag, wench.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: So methinks ; but for your comfort I can tell you, we have a doctor in the city that undertakes the cure of such.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.p: Tush, I know what physic is best for the state of mine own body.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: 'Tis scarce a well governed state, I believe.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.p: I could show thee such a thing with an ingredient that we two would compound together, and if it did not tame the maddest blood i'th town for two hours after, I'll ne'er profess physic again.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: A little poppy sir, were good to cause you sleep.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.p: Poppy; I'll give thee a pop i'th lips for that first, and begin there: poppy is one simple indeed, and cuckoo (What you call't) another: I'll discover no more now, another time I'll show thee all.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: My father, sir.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: O Joanna, I came to meet thee, your devotion's ended.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: For this time, sir,
I shall change my saint, I fear me, I find
A giddy turning in me; sir, this while
I am beholding to this gentleman
Who left his own way to keep me company,
And in discourse I find him much desirous
To see your castle: he hath deserved it, sir,
If ye please to grant it.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: With all my heart, sir.
Yet there's an article between, I must know
Your country; we use not to give survey
Of our chief strengths to strangers, our citadels
Are placed conspicuous to outward view,
On promont's tops; but within are secrets.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: A Valentian, sir.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: A Valentian,
That's native, sir; of what name, I beseech you?

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Alsemero, sir.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Alsemero; not the son of John de Alsemero?

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: The same sir.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: My best love bids you welcome.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: He was wont to call me so, and then he speaks
A most unfeigned truth.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: O sir, I knew your father,
We two were in acquaintance long ago
Before our chins were worth Julan down,
And so continued till the stamp of time
Had coined us into silver: well, he's gone,
A good soldier went with him.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: You went together in that, sir.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: No by saint Jaques, I came behind him.
Yet I have done somewhat too, an unhappy day
Swallowed him at last at Gibralter
In fight with those rebellious Hollanders,
Was it not so?

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Whose death I had revenged,
Or followed him in fate, had not the late league
Prevented me.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Ay, ay, 'twas time to breathe:
O Joanna, I should he told thee news,
I saw Piracquo lately.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: That's ill news.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: He's hot preparing for this day of triumph,
Thou must be a bride within this seven-night.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Nay good sir, be not so violent, with speed
I cannot render satisfaction
Unto the dear companion of my soul,
Virginity (Whom I thus long have lived with)
And part with it so rude and suddenly,
Can such friends divide never to meet again,
Without a solemn farewell?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Tush, tush, there's a toy.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: I must now part, and never meet again
With any joy on earth; sir, your pardon,
My affairs call on me.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: How sir? by no means,
not changed so soon, I hope, you must see my castle,
And her best entertainment ere we part,
I shall think myself unkindly used else.
Come, come, let's on, I had good hope your stay
Had been a while with us in Alligant;
I might have bid you to my daughter's wedding.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: He means to feast me, and poisons me before hand,
I should be dear glad to be there, sir,
Did my occasions suit as I could wish.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I shall be sorry if you be not there
When it is done sir, but not so suddenly.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I tell you, sir, the gentleman's complete,
A courtier and a gallant, enriched
With many fair and noble ornaments,
I would not change him for a son-in-law,
For any he in Spain, the proudest he,
And we have great ones, that you know.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: He's much bound to you, sir.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: He shall be bound to me,
As fast as this tie can hold him, I'll want my will else.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I shall want mine if you do it.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: But come, by the way, I'll tell you more of him:

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: How shall I dare to venture in his castle,
When he discharges murderers at the gate?
But I must on, for back I cannot go.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Not this serpent gone yet?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Look girl, thy glove's fallen,
Stay, stay, Deflores help a little.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Here, lady.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Mischief on your officious forwardness,
Who bade you stoop? they touch my hand no more:
There, for tother's sake I part with this,
Take they and draw thine own skin off with 'em.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Here's a favour come; with a mischief: now
I know she had rather wear my pelt tanned
In a pair of dancing pumps, than I should thrust my fingers;
Into her sockets here I know she hates me,
Yet cannot choose but love her:
No matter, if but to vex her, I'll haunt her still,
Though I get nothing else, I'll have my will.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: Lollio, I must trust thee with a secret,
But thou must keep it.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: I was ever close to a secret, sir.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: The diligence that I have found in thee,
The care and industry already past,
Assures me of thy good continuance.

sp.speaker: Lollio,
sp.l: I have a wife.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Fie sir, 'tis too late to keep her secret, she's known to be married all the town and country over.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: Thou goest too fast my Lollio, that knowledge
I allow no man can be barred it;
But there is a knowledge which is nearer,
Deeper and sweeter, Lollio.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Well sir, let us handle that between you and I.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: 'Tis that I go about man; Lollio,
My wife is young,

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: So much the worse to be kept secret, sir.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: Why now thou meetest the substance of the point,
I am old, Lollio.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: No sir, 'tis I am old Lollio.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: Yet why may not this concord and sympathize?
Old trees and young plants often grow together,
Well enough agreeing.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Ay sir, but the old trees raise themselves higher and broader than the young plants.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: Shrewd application: there's the fear man,
I would wear my ring on my own finger;
Whilst it is borrowed it is none of mine,
But his that useth it.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: You must keep it on still then, if it but lie by,
One or other will be thrusting into't.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: Thou conceivest me Lollio, here thy watchful eye
Must have employment, I cannot always be at home.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: I dare swear you cannot.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: I must look out.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: I know't, you must look out, 'tis every man's case.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: Here I do say must thy employment be.
To watch her treadings, and in my absence
Supply my place.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: I'll do my best, sir, yet surely I cannot see who you should have cause to be jealous of.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.p: Thy reason for that Lollio, 'tis a comfortable question.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: We have but two sorts of people in the house, and both under the whip, that's fools and madmen; the one has not wit enough to be knaves, and the other not knavery enough to be fools.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: I those are all my patients, Lollio.
I do profess the cure of either sort:
My trade, my living 'tis, I thrive by it;
But here's the care that mixes with my thrift,
The daily visitants, that come to see
My brainsick patients, I would not have
To see my wife: gallants I do observe
Of quick enticing eyes, rich in habits,
Of stature and proportion very comely:
These are most shrewd temptations, Lollio.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: They may be easily answered, sir, if they come to see the fools and madmen, you and I may serve the turn, and let my mistress alone, she's of neither sort.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: 'Tis a good ward, indeed come they to see
Our madmen or our fools, let they see no more
Than what they come for; by that consequent
They must not see her, I'm sure she's no fool.

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.l: And I'm sure she's no madman.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: Hold that buckler fast, Lollio my trust
Is on thee, and I account it firm and strong.
What hour is't Lollio?

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Towards belly hour sir.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: Dinner time, thou meanest twelve o'clock .

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Yes sir, for every part has his hour, we wake at six and look about us, that's eye-hour; at seven we should pray, that's knee-hour; at eight walk, that's leg hour; at nine gather flowers, and pluck a rose, that's nose-hour; at ten we drink, that's mouth hour; at eleven lay about us for victuals, that's hand hour; at twelve go to dinner, that's belly hour.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: Profoundly, Lollio it will be long
Ere all thy scholars learn this lesson, and
I did look to have a new one entered — stay
I think my expectation is come home.

div.stage: Enter Pedro and Antonio like an idiot.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Save you sir, my business speaks itself,
This sight takes off the labour of my tongue.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: Ay, I sir, 'tis plain enough, you mean him for my patient.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: And if your pains prove but commodious,
To give but some little strength to his sick
And weak part of nature in him, these are
But patterns to show you of the whole pieces
That will follow to you, beside the charge
Of diet washing, and other necessaries
Fully defrayed.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: Believe it, sir, there shall no care be wanting.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Sir, an officer in this place may deserve something,
The trouble will pass through my hands.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: 'Tis fit something should come to your hands then, sir.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Yes, sir, 'tis I must keep him sweet, and read to him, what is his name.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: His name is Antonio, marry we use but half to him, only Tony.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Tony, Tony, 'tis enough, and a very good name for a fool, what's your name Tony?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: He, he he, well I thank you cousin, he he, he.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Good boy hold up your head: he can laugh, I perceive by that he is no beast.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Well sir, if you can raise him but to any height,
Any degree of wit, might he attain
(As I might say) to creep but on all four,
Towards the chair of wit, or walk on crutches,
'Twould add an honour to your worthy pains,
And a great family might pray for you,
To which he should be heir, had he discretion
To claim and guide his own; assure you sir,
He is a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Nay, there's nobody doubted that, at first sight I knew him for a gentleman, he looks no other yet.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Let him have good attendance and sweet lodging.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: As good as my mistress lies in sir, and as you allow us time and means, we can raise him to the higher degree of discretion.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Nay, there shall no cost want sir.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: He will hardly be stretched up to the wit of a magnifico.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: O no, that's not to be expected, far shorter
Will be enough.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: I'll warrant you make him fit to bear office in five weeks,
I'll undertake to wind him up to the wit of constable.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: If it be lower than that it might serve turn.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: No fie, to level him with a headborough, beadle, or watchman, were but little better than he is; constable I'll able him: if he do come to be a justice afterwards, let him thank the keeper. Or I'll go further with you, say I do bring him up to my own pitch, say I make him as wise as myself.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Why there I would have it.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Well, go to, either I'll be as errant a fool as he, or he shall be as wise as I, and then I think 'twill serve his turn.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Nay, I do like thy wit passing well.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Yes, you may, yet if I had not been a fool, I had had more wit than I have too remember what state you find me in.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I will, and so leave you: your best cares I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: Take you none with you, leave they all with us.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O my cousin's gone, cousin, cousin, o.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Peace, peace Tony, you must not cry child, you must be whipped if you do, your cousin is here still, I am your cousin, Tony.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: He, he, then I'll not cry, if thou beest my cousin, he, he, he.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: I were best try his wit a little, that I may know what form to place him in.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.p: Ay, do Lollio, do.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: I must ask him easy questions at first; Tony, how many true fingers has a tailor on his right hand?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: As many as on his left, cousin.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Good, and how many on both?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Two less than a deuce, cousin.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Very well answered; I come to you again, cousin Tony, how many fools goes to a wise man?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Forty in a day sometimes, cousin.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Forty in a day? How prove you that?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: All that fall out amongst themselves, and go to a lawyer to be made friends.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: A perilous fool, he must sit in the fourth form at least, I perceive that: I come again Tony, how many knaves make an honest man?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I know not that cousin.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: No, the question is too hard for you: I'll tell you cousin, there's three knaves may make an honest man, a sergeant, a jailor, and a beadle; the sergeant catches him, the jailor holds him, and the beadle lashes him; and if he be not honest then, the hangman must cure him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, that's fine sport cousin.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: This was too deep a question for the fool Lollio.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Yes, this might have served yourself, though I say't;
Once more, and you shall go play Tony.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ay, play at push-pin in cousin, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: So thou shalt, say how many fools are here.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Two, cousin, thou and I.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Nay, you're too forward there, Tony mark my question, how many fools and knaves are here? A fool before a knave, a fool behind a knave, between every two fools a knave, how many fools, how many knaves?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I never learned so far cousin.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: Thou puttest too hard questions to him, Lollio.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: I'll make him understand it easily; cousin stand there.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I cousin.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Master, stand you next the fool.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: Well, Lollio.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Here's my place: mark now Tony, there a fool before a knave.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That's I cousin.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Here's a fool behind a knave, that's I, and between us two fools there is a knave, that's my master, 'tis but we three, that's all.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: We three, we three, cousin.

sp.speaker: 1 within.
sp.l: Put's head i'th pillory, the breads too little.

sp.speaker: 2 within.
sp.l: Fly, fly, and he catches the swallow.

sp.speaker: 3. Within.
sp.p: Give her more onion, or the devil put the rope about her crag.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: You may hear what time of day it is, the chimes of bedlam goes.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: Peace, peace, or the wire comes.

sp.speaker: 3 within.
sp.l: Cat whore, cat whore, her permasant, her permasant.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: Peace, I say, their hour's come, they must be fed, Lollio.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: There's no hope of recovery of that Welsh madman,
Was undone by a mouse, that spoilt him a permasant,
Lost his wits for 't.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: Go to your charge, Lollio, I'll to mine.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Go you to your madmen's ward, let me alone with your fools.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.p: And remember my last charge, Lollio.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Of which your patients do you think I am? Come Tony you must amongst your schoolfellows now, there's pretty scholars amongst they, I can tell you there's some of 'em at stultus, stulta, stultum.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I would see the madmen, cousin, if they would not bite me.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: No, they shall not bite thee, Tony.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: They bite when they are at dinner, do they not coz.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: They bite at dinner indeed, Tony; well, I hope to get credit by thee, I like thee the best of all the scholars that ever I brought up, and thou shalt prove a wise man, or I'll prove a fool myself.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: O sir, I'm ready now for that fair service,
Which makes the name of friend sit glorious on you.
Good angels and this conduct be your guide,
Fitness of time and place is there set down, sir.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: The joy I shall return rewards my service.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: How wise is Alsemero in his friend?
It is a sign he makes his choice with judgement.
Then I appear in nothing more approved,
Then making choice of him; for 'tis a principle, he that can choose
That bosom well, who of his thoughts partakes,
Proves most discreet in every choice he makes.
Methinks I love now with the eyes of judgement.
And see the way to merit, clearly see it.
A true deserver like a diamond sparkles,
In darkness you may see him, that's in absence,
Which is the greatest darkness falls on love,
Yet is he best discerned then
With intellectual eyesight; what's Piracquo
My father spends his breath for, and his blessing
is only mine, as I regard his name,
Else it goes from me, and turns head against me,
Transformed into a curse; some speedy way
Must be remembered, he's so forward too,
So urgent that way, scarce allows me breath
To speak to my new comforts.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Yonder's she
Whatever ails me, now a late especially,
I can as well be hanged as refrain seeing her;
Some twenty times aday, nay not so little,
Do I force errands, frame ways and excuses
To come into her sight, and I have small reason for't,
And less encouragement; for she baits me still
Every time worse than other, does profess herself
The cruelest enemy to my face, in town,
At no hand can abide the sight of me,
As if danger, or ill luck hung in my looks.
I must confess my face is bad enough,
But I know far worse has better fortune,
And not endured alone, but doted on,
And yet such pickhaired faces, chins like witches,
Here and there five hairs, whispering in a corner,
As if they grew in fear one of another,
Wrinkles like troughs, where swine deformity swills
The tears of perjury that lie there like wash,
Fallen from the slimy and dishonest eye,
Yet such a one plucked sweets without restraint,
And has the grace of beauty to his sweet,
Though my hard fate has thrust me out to servitude,
I tumbled into th'world a gentleman.
She turns her blessed eye upon me now,
And I'll endure all storms before I part with't.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Again — this ominous ill-faced fellow more disturbs me,
Than all my other passions.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Now't begins again,
I'll stand this storm of hail though the stones pelt me.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Thy business? What's thy business?

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Soft and fair, I cannot part so soon now.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: The villain's fixed — thou standing toad-pool.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: The shower falls amain now.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Who sent thee? What's thy errand? leave my sight.

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: My lord your father charged me to deliver a message to you.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: What another since, do't and be hanged then, let me be rid of thee.

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: True service merits mercy.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: What's thy message?

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: Let beauty settle but in patience, you shall hear all.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: A dallying trifling torment.

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: Signior Alonzo de Piracquo lady, sole brother to Tomazo de Piracquo.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: Slave, when wil't make an end?

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: Too soon I shall.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: What all this while of him?

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: The said Alonzo, with the foresaid Tomazo.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: Yet again.

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: Is new alighted.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: Vengeance strike the news,
Thou thing most loathed, what cause was there in this
To bring thee to my sight?

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: My lord your father charged me to seek you out.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: Is there no other to send his errand by?

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: It seems 'tis my luck to be i'th way still.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: Get thee from me.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: So — why am not I an ass to devise ways
Thus to be railed at? I must see her still,
I shall have a mad qualm within this hour again,
I know't, and like a common garden bull,
I do but take breath to be lugged again.
What this may bode I know not, I'll despair the less,
Because there's daily presidents of bad faces
Beloved beyond all reason; these foul chops
May come into favour one day, amongst his fellows:
Wrangling has proved the mistress of good pastime,
As children cry themselves asleep, I ha' seen
Women have chid themselves a-bed to men.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I never see this fellow, but I think
Of some harm towards me, danger's in my mind still,
I scarce leave trembling of an hour after.
The next good mood I find my father in,
I'll get him quite discarded: o I was
Lost in this small disturbance and forgotten.
Afflictions fiercer torrent that now comes,
To bear down all my comforts.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: You're both welcome,
But an especial one belongs to you, sir,
To whose most noble name our love presents
The addition of a son, our son Alonzo.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: The treasury of honour cannot bring forth
A title I should more rejoice in, sir.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: You have improved it well; daughter prepare,
The day will steal upon thee suddenly.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Howe'er , I will be sure to keep the night,
If it should come so near me.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Alonzo.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Brother.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: In troth I see small welcome in her eye.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Fie, you are too severe a censurer
Of love in all points, there's no bringing on you
If lovers should mark every thing a fault,
Affection would be like an ill set book,
Whose faults might prove as big as half the volume.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: That's all I do entreat.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: It is but reasonable,
I'll see what my son says to't: son Alonzo,
Here's a motion made but to reprieve
A maidenhead three days longer; the request
Is not far out of reason, for indeed
The former time is pinching.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Though my joys
Be set back so much time as I could wish
They had been forward, yet since she desires it,
The time is set as pleasing as before,
I find no gladness wanting.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: May I ever meet it in that point still:
You're nobly welcome, sirs.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: So, did you mark the dulness of her parting now?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: What dulness? Thou art so exceptious still.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Why let it go then I am but a fool
To mark your harms so heedfully.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Where's the oversight?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Come, your faith's cozened in her, strongly cozened,
Unsettle your affection with all speed,
Wisdom can bring it too, your peace is ruined else.
Think what a torment 'tis to marry one
Whose heart is leapt into another's bosom:
If ever pleasure she receive from thee,
It comes not in thy name, or of thy gift,
She lies but with another in thine arms,
He the half father unto all thy children
In the conception, if he get 'em not,
She helps to get 'em for him, in his passions, and how dangerous
And shameful her restraint may go in time to,
It is not to be thought on without sufferings.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: You speak as if she loved some other then.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Do you apprehend so slowly?

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Nay, and that be your fear only, I am safe enough,
Preserve your friendship and your counsel brother,
For times of more distress, I should depart
An enemy, a dangerous, deadly one
To any but thyself, that should but think
She knew the meaning of inconstancy,
Much less the use and practice; yet we're friends,
Pray let no more be urged, I can endure
Much, till I meet an injury to her,
Than I am not myself. Farewell sweet brother,
How much we're bound to heaven to depart lovingly.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Why here is love's tame madness, thus a man
Quickly steals into his vexation.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: The place is my charge, you have kept your hour,
And the reward of a just meeting bless you.
I hear my lady coming; complete gentleman,
I dare not be too busy with my praises,
They're dangerous things to deal with.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: This goes well, these women are the ladies' cabinets,
Things of most precious trust are lock into 'em.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I have within mine eye, all my desires,
Requests that holy prayers ascend heaven for '
And brings 'em down to furnish our defects,
come not more sweet to our necessities,
Than thou unto my wishes.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: We're so like in our expressions, lady, that unless I borrow
The same words, I shall never find their equals.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: How happy were this meeting this embrace,
If it were free from envy? This poor kiss
It has an enemy, a hateful one,
That wishes poison to't: how well were I now
If there were none such name known as Piracquo?
Nor no such tie as the command of parents,
I should be but too much blessed.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: One good service
Would strike off both your fears, and I'll go near it too,
Since you are so distressed, remove the cause
The command ceases, so there's two fears blown out
With one and the same blast.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Pray let me find you sir. What might that service be so strangely happy?

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: The honourablest piece about man, valour.
I'll send a challenge to Piracquo instantly.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: How? Call you that extinguishing of fear
When 'tis the only way to keep it flaming?
Are not you ventured in the action,
That's all my joys and comforts? Pray no more, sir.
Say you prevailed, your dangers and not mine then
The law would claim you from me, or obscurity
Be made the grave to bury you alive.
I'm glad these thoughts come forth, oh keep not one
Of this condition sir; here was a course
Found to bring sorrow on her way to death:
The tears would never a dried, till dust had choked 'em.
Bloodguiltiness becomes a fouler visage,
And now I think on one — I was too blame,
I ha' marred so good a market with my scorn;
'T had been done questionless, the ugliest creature
Creation framed for some use, yet to see
I could not mark so much where it should be.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Lady.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Why men of art make much of poison,
Keep one to expel another, where was my art?

sp.speaker: Als:
sp.l: Lady, you hear not me.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I do especially sir, the present times are not so sure of our side
As those hereafter may be, we must use 'em then
As thrifty folks their wealth, sparingly, now till the time opens.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: You teach wisdom, lady.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Within there Diaphanta.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Do you call, madam?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Perfect your service, and conduct this gentleman
The private way you brought him.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I shall, madam.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: My love's as firm as love e'er built upon.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: I have watched this meeting, and do wonder much
What shall become of tother, I'm sure both
Cannot be served unless she transgress; happily
Then I'll put in for one: for if a woman
Fly from one point, from him she makes a husband,
She spreads and mounts then like arithmetic,
1, 10, 100, 1000, 10000, proves in time sutler to an army royal.
Now do I look to be most richly railed at,
Yet I must see her.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Why, put case I loathed him
As much as youth and beauty hates a sepulchre,
Must I needs show it? Cannot I keep that secret,
And serve my turn upon him? — see he's here — Deflores.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Ha, I shall run mad with joy,
She called me fairly by my name Deflores,
And neither rogue nor rascal.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: What ha' you done to your face o'late? you've met with some good physician,
You've pruned yourself methinks , you were not wont
To look so amorously.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Not I, 'tis the same phisnomy to a hair and pimple,
Which she called scurvy scarce an hour ago: how is this?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Come hither, nearer man.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: I'm up to the chin in heaven.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Turn, let me see, vauh 'tis but the heat of the liver, I perceive't.
I thought it had been worse.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Her fingers touched me, she smells all amber.

sp.speaker: Bea
sp.l: I'll make a water for you shall cleanse this within a fortnight.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: With your own hands, lady?

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: Yes, mine own sir, in a work of cure, I'll trust no other.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: 'Tis half an act of pleasure to hear her talk thus to me.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: When we're used to a hard face, 'tis not so unpleasing,
It mends still in opinion, hourly mends, I see it by experience.

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: I was blessed to light upon this minute, I'll make use on't.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: Hardness becomes the visage of a man well,
It argues service, resolution, manhood, if cause were of employment.

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: 'Twould be soon seen, if e'er your ladyship had cause to use it.
I would but wish the honour of a service so happy as that mounts to.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: We shall try you — o my Deflores!

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: How's that? She calls me hers already, my Deflores,
You were about to sigh out somewhat, madam.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: No, was I? I forgotten — oh!

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: There 'tis again — the very fellow on't.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: You are too quick, sir.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: There's no excuse for't, now I heard it twice, madam,
That sigh would fain have utterance, take pity on't,
And lend it a free word, alas how it labours
For liberty, I hear the murmur yet beat at your bosom.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Would creation —

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: I well said, that's it.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Had formed me man.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Nay, that's not it.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: O 'tis the soul of freedom, I should not then be forced to marry one I hate beyond all depths, I should have power then to oppose my loathings, nay remove 'em for ever from my sight.

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.p: O blessed occasion — without change to your sex, you have your wishes.
Claim so much man in me.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: In thee Deflores? There's small cause for that.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Put it not from me, it's a service that I kneel for to you.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: You are too violent to mean faithfully,
There's horror in my service, blood and danger,
Can those be things to sue for?

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: If you knew how sweet it were to me to be employed
In any act of yours, you would say then
I failed, and used not reverence enough
When I receive the charge on't.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: This is much methinks, belike his wants are greedy, and to such
gold tastes like angel's food — rise.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: I'll have the work first.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Possible his need is strong upon him, there's to encourage thee
As thou art forward and thy service dangerous,
Thy reward shall be precious.

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.p: That I have thought on, I have assured myself of that before hand, and know it will be precious, the thought ravishes.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Then take him to thy fury.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: I thirst for him.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: Alonzo de Piracquo.

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: His ends upon him, he shall be seen no more.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: How lovely now dost thou appear to me!
Never was man dearlier rewarded.

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: I do think of that.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Be wondrous careful in the execution.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Why? are not both our lives upon the cast?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Then I throw all my fears upon thy service.

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: They never shall rise to hurt you.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: When the deed's done, I'll furnish thee with all things for thy flight, thou mayst live bravely in another country.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Ay, ay, we'll talk of that hereafter.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I shall rid myself of two inveterate loathings at one time,
Piracquo and his dog-face.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: O my blood, methinks I feel her in mine arms already.
Her wanton fingers combing out this beard,
And being pleased, praising this bad face.
Hunger and pleasure they'll commend sometimes
Slovenly dishes, and feed heartily on 'em,
Nay which is stranger, refuse daintier for 'em.
Some women are odd feeders — I'm too loud.
Here comes the man goes supperless to bed,
Yet shall not rise tomorrow to his dinner.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Deflores.

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: My kind honourable lord.

sp.speaker: Alon:
sp.l: I am glad I ha' met with thee.

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Thou canst show me the full strength of the castle,

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: That I can sir.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: I much desire it.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.p: And if the ways and straits of some of the passages be not too tedious for you, I will assure you worth your time and sight, my lord.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Puh, that shall be no hindrance.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: I'm your servant then: 'tis now near dinner time, 'gainst your
Lordship's rising I'll have the keys about me.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Thanks kind Deflores.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: He's safely thrust upon me beyond hopes

div.head: Actus tertius.
div.stage: (In the act time Deflores hides a naked rapier.)

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Yes, here are all the keys, I was afraid my lord,
I'd wanted for the postern, this is it.
I've all, I've all, my lord: this for the sconce.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: 'Tis a most spacious and impregnable fort.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: You'll tell me more my lord: this descent
Is somewhat narrow, we shall never pass
Well with our weapons, they'll but trouble us.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Thou sayst true.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Pray let me help your lordship.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: 'Tis done. Thanks kind Deflores.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Here are hooks my lord, to hang such things on purpose.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Lead, I'll follow thee.

div.stage: Ex. at one door and enter at the other.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: All this is nothing, you shall see anon a place you little dream on

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: I am glad I have this leisure: all your master's house
Imagine I had taken a gondola.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: All but myself, sir, which makes up my safety,
My lord, I'll place you at a casement here,
Will show you the full strength of all the castle.
Look, spend your eye a while upon that object.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Here's rich variety Deflores.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: Goodly munition.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.p:
Ay, there's ordnance sir, no bastard metal, will ring you a peal
like bells at greet men's funerals; keep your eye straight, my lord, take special notice of that scone before you, there you may dwell awhile.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: I am upon't.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: And so am I.

sp.speaker: Alon:
sp.l: Deflores, o Deflores, whose malice hast thou put on?

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: Do you question a work of secrecy? I must silence you.

sp.speaker: Alon.
sp.l: O, o, o.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: I must silence you.
So, here's an undertaking well accomplished.
This vault serves to good use now — ha! what's that
Threw sparkles in my eye? — o 'tis a diamond
He wears upon his finger: it was well found,
This will approve the work. What, so fast on?
Not part in death? I'll take a speedy course then,
Finger and all shall off. So, now I'll clear
The passages from all suspect or fear.

sp.speaker: Isa:
sp.l: Why sirrah? Whence have you commission
To fetter the doors against me? If you
Keep me in a cage, pray whistle to me,
Let me be doing something.

sp.speaker: Lol:
sp.l: You shall be doing, if it please you, I'll whistle to you if you'll pipe after.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Is it your master's pleasure, or your own,
To keep me in this pinfold?

sp.speaker: Lol:
sp.l: 'Tis for my master's pleasure, lest being taken in another man's
Corn, you might be pounded in another place.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: 'Tis very well, and he'll prove very wise.

sp.speaker: Lol:
sp.p: He says you have company enough in the house, if you please to be sociable, of all sorts of people.

sp.speaker: Isa:
sp.p: Of all sorts? Why here's none but fools and madmen.

sp.speaker: Lol:
sp.p: Very well: and where will you find any other, if you should go abroad? There's my master and I to boot too:

sp.speaker: Isa:
sp.l: Of either sort one, a madman and a fool.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: I would e'en participate of both then if were as you, I know you're half mad already; be half foolish too.

sp.speaker: Isa:
sp.l: You're a brave saucy rascal, come on sir,
Afford me then the pleasure of your bedlam;
You were commending once today to me,
Your last come lunatic, what a proper
body there was without brains to guide it,
And what a pitiful delight appeared
In that defect, as if your wisdom had found
A mirth in madness; pray sir let me partake
If there be such a pleasure.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: If I do not show
You the handsomest, discreetest madman, one that I may
Call, the understanding madman; then say I am a fool.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Well, a match, I will say so.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: When you have a taste of the madman, you shall (If you please) see fool's college, o'th side, I seldom lock there, 'tis but shooting a bolt or two, and you are amongst 'em.
sp.l: Come on sir, let me see how handsomely you'll behave yourself now.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: How sweetly she looks! O but there's a wrinkle in her brow as deep as philosophy, Anacreon drink to my mistress health, I'll pledge it: stay, stay, there's a spider in the cup: no, 'tis but a grapestone, swallow it, fear nothing poet; so, so, lift higher.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Alack, alack, 'tis too full of pity
To be laughed at; how fell he mad? Canst thou tell?

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: For love, mistress,
He was a pretty poet too, and that set him forwards first;
The muses then forsook him, he ran mad for a chambermaid,
Yet she was but a dwarf neither.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Hail bright Titania, why standst thou idle on these flowery banks? Oberon is dancing with his dryads, I'll gather daisies, primrose, violets, and bind them in a verse of poesy.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Not too near, you see your danger.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: O hold thy hand great Diomed, thou feedest thy horses well, they shall obey thee; get up, Bucephalus kneels.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: You see how I awe my flock, a shepherd has not his dog at more obedience.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: His conscience is unquiet, sure that was
The cause of this. A proper gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Come hither Esculapius, hide the poison.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Well, 'tis hid.

sp.speaker: Fran
sp.l: Didst thou never hear of one Tiresias a famous poet?

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Yes, that kept tame wildgeese.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: That's he, I am the man.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Fra:
sp.l: Yes, but make no words on't, I was a man seven years ago,

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: A stripling I think you might.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Now I'm a woman, all feminine.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: I would I might see that.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Juno struck me blind,

sp.speaker: Lol:
sp.p: I'll never believe that; for a woman they say, has an eye more than a man.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I say she struck me blind.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: And luna made you mad, you have two trades to beg with.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Luna is now big bellied, and there's room for both of us to ride with Hecate; I'll drag thee up into her silver sphere, and there we'll kick the dog, and beat the bush that barks against the witches of the night, the swift licanthropi that walks the round, we'll tear their wolvish skins, and save the sheep.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Is't come to this? nay then my poison comes forth again, mad slave, indeed, abuse your keeper!

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I prithee hence with him, now he grows dangerous.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sweet love pity me, give me leave to lie with thee.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: No, I'll see you wiser first: to your own kennel.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: No noise she sleeps, draw all the curtains round,
Let no soft sound molest the pretty soul,
But love, and love, creeps in at a mousehole.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: I would you would get into your hole.
sp.p: Now mistress I will bring you another sort, you shall be fooled another while, Tony, come hither Tony, look who's yonder Tony.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Cousin, is it not my aunt?

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Yes, 'tis on of they Tony.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He, he, how do you uncle?

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Fear him not mistress, 'tis a gentle nigget, you may play with him, as safely with him as with his bauble.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: How long hast thou been a fool?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ever since I came hither, cousin?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Cousin, I'm none of thy cousin's fool.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: O mistress, fools have always so much wit as to claim their kindred.

sp.speaker: Madman
sp.l: Bounce, bounce, he falls, he falls.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Hark you, your scholars in the upper room are out of order.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Must I come amongst you there? Keep you the fool mistress, I'll go up, and play left handed Orlando amongst the madmen.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Well, sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis opportuneful now, sweet lady! nay,
Cast no amazing eye upon this change.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This shape of folly shrowds your dearest love,
The truest servant to your powerful beauties,
Whose magic had this force thus to transform me.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: You are a fine fool indeed.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O 'tis not strange: love has an intellect that runs through all
The scrutinous sciences; and like
A cunning poet, catches a quantity
Of every knowledge, yet brings all home
Into one mystery, into one secret
That he proceeds in.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: You're a perilous fool.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No danger in me: I bring naught but love,
And his soft wounding shafts to strike you with:
Try but one arrow; if it hurt you,
I'll stand you twenty back in recompense.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: A forward fool too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This was Love's teaching:
A thousand ways she fashioned out my way,
And this I found the safest and nearest
To tread the gallaxia to my star.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Profound, withal certain: you dreamed of this;
Love never taught it waking.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Take no acquaintance of these outward follies; there is within
A gentleman that loves you.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: When I see him, I'll speak with him; so in the mean time
Keep your habit, it becomes you well enough
As you are a gentleman, I'll not discover you;
That's all the favour that you must expect:
When you are weary, you may leave the school,
For all this while you have but played the fool.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And must again; he, he, I thank you cousin, I'll be your Valentine tomorrow morning.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: How do you like the fool, mistress?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Passing well, sir.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Is he not witty, pretty well for a fool?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: If he hold on as he begins, he is like to come to something ▪

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Ay, thank a good tutor: you may put him to't; he begins
To answer pretty hard questions. Tony, how many is
Five times six?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Five times six, is six times five.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: What arithmetician could have answered better? how many is one hundred and seven?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: One hundred and seven, is seven hundred and one, cousin.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: This is no wit to speak on; will you be rid of the fool now?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: By no means, let him stay a little:

sp.speaker: Madman
sp.l: Catch there, catch the last couple in hell.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Again, must I come amongst you? Would my master were come home! I am not able to govern both these wards together.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why should a minute of love's hour be lost?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Fie, out again! I had rather you kept
Your other posture: you become not your tongue,
When you speak from your clothes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How can he freeze, lives near so sweet a warmth? shall I alone
Walk through the orchard of the hesperides.
And cowardly not dare to pull an apple?
This with the red cheeks I must venture for.

sp.speaker: Isa:
sp.l: Take heed, there's giants keep 'em.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: How now fool, are you good at that? have you read Lipsius?
He's past ars amandi; I believe I must put harder
Questions to him, I perceive that —

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: You are bold without fear too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What should I fear, having all joys about me? Do you smile,
And love shall play the wanton on your lip,
Meet and retire, retire and meet again:
Look you but cheerfully, and in your eyes
I shall behold mine own deformity,
And dress myself up fairer; I know this shape
Becomes me not, but in those bright mirrors
I shall array me handsomely.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Cuckoo, cuckoo —

sp.speaker: Madmen
sp.l: Some as birds, others as beasts.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What are these?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Of fear enough to part us, yet are they but our schools of lunatiques,
sp.l: That act their fantasies in any shapes
Suiting their present thoughts; if sad, they cry;
If mirth be their conceit, they laugh again.
Sometimes they imitate the beasts and birds,
Singing, or howling, braying, barking; all
As their wild fancies prompt 'em.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: These are no fears.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: But here's a large one, my man.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ha, he, that's fine sport indeed, cousin:

sp.speaker: Lol:
sp.p: I would my master were come home, 'tis too much for one shepherd to govern two of these flocks; nor can I believe that one churchman can instruct two benefices at once, there will be some incurable mad of the one side, and very fools on the other. Come Tony.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Prithee cousin, let me stay here still.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: No, you must to your book now you have played sufficiently.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Your fool is grown wondrous witty.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Well, I'll say nothing; but I do not think but he will put you down one of these days.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Here the restrained current might make breach,
Spite of the watchful bankers, would a woman stray,
She need not gad abroad to seek her sin,
It would be brought home one ways or other:
The needles point will to the fixed North,
Such drawing Articks women's beauties are.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: How dost thou sweet rogue?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Come, there are degrees, one fool may be better than another

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Lol:
sp.l: Nay, if thou givest thy mind to fools-flesh, have at thee.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: You bold slave you.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: I could follow now as tother fool did,
What should I fear, having all joys about me: do you but smile,
And love shall play the wanton on your lip,
Meet and retire, retire and meet again:
Look you but cheerfully, and in your eyes,
I shall behold my own deformity,
And dress myself up fairer, I know this shape
becomes me not; and so as it follows, but is not this the more
Foolish way? Come sweet rogue, kiss me my little Lacedaemonian.
Let me feel how thy pulses beat; thou hast a thing
About thee, would do a man pleasure, I'll lay my hand on't.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Sirrah, no more I see you have discovered
This love's knight arrant, who hath made adventure
For purchase of my love; be silent, mute,
Mute as a statue, or his injunction
For me enjoying, shall be to cut thy throat,
I'll do it, though for no other purpose,
And be sure he'll not refuse it.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: My share, that's all, I'll have my fools part with you

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: No more your master.

sp.speaker: Alib:
sp.l: Sweet, how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Your bounden servant, sir.

sp.speaker: Alib:
sp.l: Fie, fie, sweet heart, no more of that.

sp.speaker: Isa:
sp.l: You were best lock me up.

sp.speaker: Alib:
sp.l: In my arms and bosom, my sweet Isabella,
I'll lock thee up most nearly. Lollio,
We have employment, we have task in hand,
At noble Vermonderos our castle captain,
There is a nuptial to be solemnised,
Beatrice Joanna his fair daughter bride,
For which the gentleman hath bespoke our pains,
A mixture of our madmen and our fools,
To finish (As it were) and make the fag
Of all the revels, the third night from the first,
Only an unexpected passage over,
To make a frightful pleasure, that is all,
But not the all I aim at; could we so act it,
To teach it in a wild distracted measure,
Though out of form and figure, breaking times head,
It were no matter, 'twould be healed again
In one age or other, if not in this,
This, this Lollio, there's a good reward begun,
And will beget a bounty be it known.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p:
This is easy, sir, I'll warrant you: you have about you fools and madmen that can dance very well, and 'tis no wonder, you best dancers are not the wisest men, the reason is, with often jumping
they jolt their brains down into their feet, that their wits lie more in their heels then in their heads.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: Honest Lollio, thou givest me a good reason,
And a comfort in it.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: You've a fine trade on't, madmen and fools are a staple-commodity.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: O wife, we must eat, wear clothes, and live,
Just at the lawyer's haven we arrive,
By madmen and by fools we both do thrive.

div.stage: Enter Vermandero, Alsemero, Jasperino, and Beatrice.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Valentia speaks so nobly of you, sir,
I wish I had a daughter now for you.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: The fellow of this creature were a partner
For a King's love.

sp.speaker: Ver:
sp.l: I had her fellow once, sir,
But heaven has married her to joys eternal,
'Twere sin to wish her in this vale again.
Come sir, your friend and you shall see the pleasures
Which my health chiefly joys in.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: I hear the beauty of this seat largely.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: It falls much short of that.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: So, here's one step
Into my father's favour, time will fix him,
I have got him now the liberty of the house,
So wisdom by degrees works out her freedom;
And if that eye be darkened that offends me,
I wait but that eclipse; this gentleman
Shall soon shine glorious in my father's liking,
Through the refulgent virtue of my love.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: My thoughts are at a banquet for the deed,
I feel no weight in't, 'tis but light and cheap,
For the sweet recompense, that I set down for't.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Deflores.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Lady.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Thy looks promise cheerfully.

sp.speaker: Def,
sp.l: All things are answerable, time, circumstance,
Your wishes and my service.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: Is it done then.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Piracquo is no more.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: My joys start at mine eyes, our sweetest delights
Are evermore born weeping.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: I've a token for you.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: For me?

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: But it was sent somewhat unwillingly,
I could not get the ring without the finger.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: Bless me! what hast thou done?

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: Why is that more than killing the whole man? I cut his heart strings.
A greedy hand thrust in a dish at court
In a mistake, hath had as much as this.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: 'Tis the first token my father made me send him,

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: And I made him send it back again
For his last token, I was loath to leave it,
And I'm sure dead men have no use of jewels,
He was as loath to part with't, for it stuck,
As if the flesh and it were both one substance.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: At the stags fall the keeper has his fees:
'Tis soon applied, all dead men's fees are yours, sir,
I pray bury the finger, but the stone
You may make use of shortly, the true value,
Take't of my truth, is near three hundred ducats.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: 'Twil hardly buy a capcase for ones conscience though
To keep it from the worm, as fine as 'tis.
Well, being my fees I'll take it,
Great men have taught me that, or else my merit
Would scorn the way on't.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: It might justly, sir: why thou mistakest Deflores, 'tis not given in state of recompense.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.p: No, I hope so, lady, you should soon witness my contempt to't then.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Prithee, thou lookest as if thou were't offended.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: That were strange, lady, 'tis not possible
My service should draw such a cause from you.
Offended? Could you think so? That were much
For one of my performance, and so warm
Yet in my service.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: 'Twere misery in me to give you cause, sir.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: I know so much, it were so, misery
In her most sharp condition.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: 'Tis resolved then; look you sir, here's 3000. golden florins,
I have not meanly thought upon thy merit.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: What salary? Now you move me.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: How Deflores?

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: Do you place me in the rank of verminous fellows,
To destroy things for wages? offer gold?
The life blood of man; is any thing
Valued too precious for my recompense?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I understand thee not.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: I could ha' hired a journeyman in murder at this rate,
And mine own conscience might have,
And have had the work brought home.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I'm in a labyrinth;
What will content him? I would fain be rid of him.
I'll double the sum, sir.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: You take a course to double my vexation, that's the good you do.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Bless me! I am now in worse plight than I was,
I know not what will please him: for my fears sake
I prithee make away with all speed possible.
And if thou beest so modest not to name
The sum that will content thee, paper blushes not,
Send thy demand in writing, it shall follow thee,
But prithee take thy flight.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: You must fly too then.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I?

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: I'll not stir a foot else.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: What's your meaning?

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Why are not you as guilty, in I'm sure
As deep as I? and we should stick together.
Come, your fears counsel you but ill, my absence
Would draw suspect upon you instantly,
There were no rescue for you.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: He speaks home.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Nor is it fit we two engaged so jointly,
Should part and live asunder.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: How now sir? This shows not well.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: What makes your lip so strange? This must not be betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: The man talks wildly.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Come kiss me with a zeal now.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Heaven I doubt him.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: I will not stand so long to beg 'em shortly.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Take heed Deflores of forgetfulness, 'twill soon betray us.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Take you heed first;
Faith you're grown much forgetful, you're too blame in't.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: He's bold, and I am blamed for't.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: I have eased you of your trouble, think on't, I'm in pain,
And must be eased of you; 'tis a charity,
Justice invites your blood to understand me.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I dare not.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Quickly.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: O I never shall, speak it yet further of that I may lose
What has been spoken, and no sound remain on't.
I would not hear so much offence again for such another deed.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Soft, lady, soft; the last is not yet paid for, o this act
Has put me into spirit; I was as greedy on't
As the parched earth of moisture, when the clouds weep.
Did you not mark, I wrought myself into't.
Nay sued and kneeled for't: why was all that pains took?
You see I have thrown contempt upon your gold,
Not that I want it, for I do piteously,
In order I will come unto't, and make use on't,
But 'twas not held so precious to begin with;
For I place wealth after the heels of pleasure,
And were I not resolved in my belief
That thy virginity were perfect in thee,
I should but take my recompense with grudging.
As if I had but half my hopes I agreed for.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: Why 'tis impossible thou canst be so wicked,
Or shelter such a cunning cruelty,
To make his death the murderer of my honour.
Thy language is so bold and vicious,
I cannot see which way I can forgive it with any modesty.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.p: Push, you forget yourself, a woman dipped in blood, and talk of modesty.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: O misery of sin! would I had been bound
Perpetually unto my living hate
In that Piracquo, than to hear these words.
Think but upon the distance that creation
Set 'twixt thy blood and mine, and keep thee there.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Look but into your conscience, read me there,
'tis a true book, you'll find me there you equal:
Push, fly not to your birth, but settle you
In what the act has made you, you're no more now,
You must forget your parentage to me,
You're the deed's creature, by that name
You lost your first condition, and I challenge you,
As peace and innocency has turned you out,
And made you one with me.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: With thee, foul villain?

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Yes, my fair murderess; do you urge me?
Though thou writ'st maid, thou whore in thy affection,
'Twas changed from thy first love, and that's a kind
Of whoredom in thy heart, and he's changed now,
To bring thy second on thy Alsemero,
Whom (By all sweets that ever darkness tasted,
If I enjoy thee not) thou never enjoyest,
I'll blast the hopes and joys of marriage,
I'll confess all, my life I rate at nothing.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Deflores.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: I shall rest from all lovers plagues then,
I live in pain now: that shooting eye
Will burn my heart to cinders.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: O sir, hear me.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: She that in life and love refuses me,
In death and shame my partner she shall be.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Stay, hear me once for all, I make thee master
Of all the wealth I have in gold and jewels,
Let me go poor unto my bed with honour,
And I am rich in all things.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Let this silence thee,
The wealth of all Valentia shall not buy my pleasure from me,
Can you weep fate from its determined purpose?
So soon may weep me.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Vengeance begins;
Murder I see is followed by more sins.
Was my creation in the womb so cursed,
It must engender with a viper first?

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Come, rise, and shroud your blushes in my bosom,
Silence is one of pleasures best receipts:
Thy peace is wrought for ever in this yielding.
Alas how the turtle pants! Thoul't love anon,
What thou so fearest, and faintest to venture on.

div.head: Actus quartus.
div.stage: Enter gentlemen, Vermandero meeting them with action of wonderment at the flight of Piracquo. Enter Alsemero, with Jasperino, and gallants, Vermandero points to him, the gentlemen seeming to applaud the choice, Alsemero, Jasperino, and gentlemen; Beatrice the bride following in great state, accompanied with Diaphanta, Isabella, and other gentlewomen: Deflores after all, smiling at the accident; Alonzo's ghost appears to Deflores in the midst of his smile, startles him, showing him the hand whose finger he had cut off. They pass over in great solemnity.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: This fellow has undone me endlessly,
Never was bride so fearfully distressed;
The more I think upon th'ensuing night,
And whom I am to cope with in embraces,
One both ennobled both in blood and mind,
So clear in understanding, that's my plague now,
Before whose judgement will my fault appear
Like malefactors crimes before tribunals,
There is no hiding on't, the more I dive
Into my own distress; how a wise man
Stands for a great calamity, there's no venturing
Into his bed, what course soe'er I light upon,
Without my shame, which may grow up to danger;
He cannot but in justice strangle me
As I lie by by him, as a cheater use me;
'Tis a precious craft to play with a false die
Before a cunning gamester; here's his closet,
The key left in't, and he abroad i'th park,
Sure 'twas forgotten, I'll be so bold as look in't.
Bless me! A right physician's closet 'tis,
Set round with viols, every one her mark too.
Sure he does practise physic for his own use,
Which may be safely called your great man's wisdom.
What manuscript lies here? The book of experiment,
Called secrets in nature: so 'tis, 'tis so,
How to know whether a woman be with child or no.
I hope I am not yet; if he should try though
Let me see folio 45. Here 'tis;
The leaf tucked dow upon't, the place suspicious.
If you would know whether a woman be with child, or not,
Give her two spoonfuls of the white water in glass c.
Where's that glass c: oh yonder I see't now, and if she be with child,
She sleeps full twelve hours after, if not, not
None of that water comes into my belly.
I'll know you from a hundred, I could break you now
Or turn you into milk, and so beguile
The master of the mystery, but I'll look to you.
Ha! that which is next, is ten times worse.
How to know whether a woman be a maid, or not;
If that should be applied, what would become of me?
Belike he has a strong faith of my purity,
That never yet made proof; but this he calls
A merry slight, but true experiment, the author Antonius Mizaldus.
Give the party you suspect the quantity of a spoonful of the water,
In the glass m. which upon her that is maid, makes three several
Effects, 'twill make her incontinently gape, then fall into a sudden
Sneezing, last into a violent laughing, else dull, heavy and lumpish.
Where had I been? I fear it, yet 'tis seven hours to bed time.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Cuds madam, are you here?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Seeing that wench now
A trick comes in my mind, 'tis a nice piece,
Gold cannot purchase; I come hither wench,
To look my lord.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Would I had such a cause to look him too.
Why he's ith' park madam.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: There let him be.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I madam, let him compass,
Whole parks and forests, as great rangers do,
At roosting time a little lodge can hold 'em.
Earth-conquering Alexander, that thought the world
Too narrow for him, in the end had but his pit-hole.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I fear thou art not modest, Diaphanta.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Your thoughts are so unwilling to be known, madam,
'Tis ever the bride's fashion towards bedtime,
To set light by her joys, as if she owed 'em not.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Her joys; her fears thou wouldst say.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Fear of what?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Art thou a maid, and talkest so to a maid?
You leave a blushing business behind,
Beshrew your heart for't.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Do you mean good sooth, madam?

sp.speaker: Bea,
sp.l: Well, if I'd thought upon the fear at first,
Man should have been unknown.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I will give a thousand ducats to that woman
Would try what my fear were, and tell me true
Tomorrow, when she gets from't: as she likes
I might perhaps be drawn to't.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Are you in earnest?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Do you get the woman, then challenge me,
And see if I'll fly from't; but I must tell you
This by the way, she must be a true maid,
Else there's no trial, my fears are not hers else.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Nay, she that I would put into your hands, madam shall be a maid.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: You know I should be shamed else, because she lies for me.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: 'Tis a strange humour:
But are you serious still? Would you resign
Your first night's pleasure, and give money too?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: As willingly as live; alas, the gold
Is but a by-bet to wedge in the honour.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I do not know how the world goes abroad
For faith or honesty, there's both required in this.
Madam, what say you to me, and stray no further,
I've a good mind in troth to earn your money.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: You're too quick, I fear, to be a maid.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: How? not a maid? nay then you urge me madam,
Your honourable self is not a truer
With all your fears upon you.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Bad enough then.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Then I with all my lightsome joys about me.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I'm glad to hear't then, you dare put your honesty upon an easy trial.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Easy? — any thing.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I'll come to you straight.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: She will not search me? will she?
Like the fore-woman of a female jury.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Glass m. Ay, this is it; look Diaphanta,
You take no worse than I do.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: And in so doing I will not question what 'tis, but take it.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Now if the experiment be true, 'twill praise itself,
And give me noble ease: — begins already,
There's the first symptom; and what haste it makes
To fall into the second, there by this time
Most admirable secret, on the contrary
It stirs not me a whit, which most concerns it.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Just in all things and in order,
As if 'twere circumscribed, one accident gives way unto another.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: How now wench?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, I am so so light at heart, ha, ha, ha. so pleasurable.
But one swig more, sweet madam.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Ay, tomorrow, we shall have time to sit by't.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Now I'm sad again.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: It lays itself so gently too; come wench, most honest Diaphanta I dare call thee now.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Pray tell me, madam, what trick call you this?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: I'll tell thee all hereafter; we must study the carriage of this business:

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I shall carry't well, because I love the burden.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: About midnight you must not fail to steal forth gently,
That I may use the place.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: O fear not, madam,
I shall be cool by that time: the bride's place,
And with a thousand ducats; I'm for a justice now,
I bring a portion with me, I scorn small fools.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I tell thee knave, mine honour is in question,
A thing till now free from suspicion,
Nor ever was there cause; who of my gentlemen are absent?
Tell me and truly how many, and who.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Antonio, sir, and Franciscus.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: When did they leave the castle?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Some ten days since, sir, the one intending to Briamata,
Th'other for Valentia.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: The time accuses they, a charge of murder
Is brought within my castle gate, Piracquo's murder,
I dare not answer faithfully their absence:
A strict command of apprehension
Shall pursue they suddenly, and either wipe
The stain off clear, or openly discover it.
Provide me winged warrants for the purpose.
See, I am set on again.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I claim a brother of you.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: You're too hot, seek him not here.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Yes, amongst your dearest bloods,
If my peace find no fairer satisfaction,
This is the place must yield account for him,
For here I left him, and the haste
Of this snatched marriage, gives strong testimony
Of his most certain ruin.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Certain falsehood;
This is the place indeed, his breach of faith,
Has too much marred both my abused love,
The honourable love I reserved for him,
And mocked my daughter's joy; the prepared morning
Blushed at his infidelity, he left
Contempt and scorn to throw upon those friends
Whose belief hurt 'em: o 'twas most ignoble
To take his flight so unexepectedly,
And throw such public wrongs on those that loved him

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Then this is all your answer.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: 'Tis too fair for one of his alliance; and I warn you
That this place no more see you.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: The best is, there is more ground to meet a man's revenge on.
Honest Deflores.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: That's my name indeed.
Saw you the bride? Good sweet sir, which way took she?

sp.speaker: Tom ▪
sp.l: I have blessed mine eyes from seeing such a false one.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: I'd fain get off, this man's not for my company,
I smell his brother's blood when I come near him.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Come hither kind and true one; I remember
My brother loved thee well.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: O purely, dear sir, methinks I am now again a killing on him.
He brings it so fresh to me.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Thou canst guess sirrah,
One honest friend has an instinct of jealousy
At some foul guilty person.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Alas sir, I am so charitable, I think none
Worse than myself — you did not see the bride then?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I prithee name her not. Is she not wicked?

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: No, no, a pretty easy round-packed sinner,
As your most ladies are, else you might think
I flattered her; but sir, at no hand wicked,
Till they're so old their sins and vices meet,
And they salute witches; I am called, I think sir:
His company e'en overlays my conscience.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: That Deflores has a wondrous honest heart.
He'll bring it out in time, I'm assured on't.
O here's the glorious master of the day's joy.
I will not be long till he and I do reckon sir.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: You are most welcome.
