sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: You may call that word back,
I do not think I am, nor wish to be.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: 'Tis strange you found the way to this house then.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Would I'd ne'er known the cause, I'm none of those sir,
That come to give you joy, and swill your wine,
'Tis a more precious liquor that must lay
The fiery thirst I bring.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Your words and you appear to me great strangers.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Time and our swords may make us more acquainted;
This the business.
I should have a brother in your place,
How treachery and malice have disposed of him,
I'm bound to inquire of him which holds his right:
Which never could come fairly.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: You must look to answer for that word, sir.

sp.speaker: Tom:
sp.l: Fear you not, I'll have it ready drawn at our next meeting.
Keep your day solemn. Farewell, I disturb it not,
I'll bear the smart with patience for a time.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: 'Tis somewhat ominous this, a quarrel entered
Upon this day, my innocence relieves me,
I should be wondrous sad else — Jasperino,
I have news to tell thee, strange news.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: I ha' some too,
I think as strange as yours, would I might keep
Mine, so my faith and friendship might be kept in't.
Faith sir, dispense a little with my zeal,
And let it cool in this.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: This put's me on, and blames thee for thy slowness.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: All may prove nothing,
Only a friendly fear that leapt from me, sir.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: No question it may prove nothing; let's partake it thou.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: 'Twas Diaphanta's chance, for to that wench
I pretend honest love, and she deserves it,
To leave me in a back part of the house,
A place we chose for private conference;
She was no sooner gone, but instantly
I heard your bride's voice in the next room to me;
And lending more attention, found Deflores
Louder than she.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Deflores? Thou art out now.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: You'll tell me more anon.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Still I'll prevent thee, the very sight of him is poison to her.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: That made me stagger too, but Diaphanta
At her return confirmed it.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Diaphanta!

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: Then fell we both to listen, and words passed
Like those that challenge interest in a woman:

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Peace, quench thy zeal, 'tis dangerous to thy bosom

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: Then truth is full of peril.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Such truths are — oh were she the sole glory of the earth,
Had eyes that could shoot fire into King's breasts,
And touched, she sleeps not here, yet I have time
Though night be near, to be resolved hereof,
And prithee do not weigh me by my passions.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: I never weighed friend so.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Done charitably, that key will lead thee to a pretty secret
By a Chaldean taught me, and I've
My study upon some, bring from my closet
A glass inscribed there with the letter m.
And question not my purpose.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: It shall be done sir.

sp.speaker: Als:
sp.l: How can this hang together? Not an hour since?
Her woman came pleading her lady's fears,
Delivered her for the most timorous virgin
That ever shrunk at man's name, and so modest,
She charged her weep out her request to me,
That she might come obscurely to my bosom.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: All things go well, my woman's preparing yonder
For her sweet voyage, which grieves me to lose,
Necessity compels it; I lose all else.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Push, modesty's shrine is set in yonder forehead.
I cannot be too sure though my Joanna.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Sir, I was bold to weep a message to you,
Pardon my modest fears.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: The dove's not meeker.
She's abused questionless. — o are you come, sir?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: The glass upon my life; I see the letter.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: Sir, this is m.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: 'Tis it

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I am suspected.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: How fitly our bride comes to partake with us!

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: What is't, my lord?

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: No hurt.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Sir, pardon me, I seldom taste of any composition.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: But this upon my warrant you shall venture on.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I fear 'twill make me ill.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Heaven forbid that.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I'm put now to my cunning, th'effects I know.
If I can now but feign 'em handsomely.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: It has that secret virtue it never missed, sir,
Upon a virgin.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: Treble qualitied ▪

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: By all that's virtuous it takes there, proceeds.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: This is the strangest trick to know a maid by.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, you have given me joy of heart to drink my lord.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: No, thou hast given me such joy of heart,
That never can be blasted.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: What's the matter sir?

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: See now 'tis settled in a melancholy,
Keep both the time and method, my Joanna:
Chaste as the breath of heaven, or morning's womb,
That brings the day forth, thus my love encloses thee.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: O heaven! is this the waiting moon?
Does love turn fool, run mad, and all once?
Sirrah, here's a madman, akin to the fool too,
A lunatic lover.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: No, no, not he I brought the letter from.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Compare his inside with his out, and tell me.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: The out's mad, I'm sure of that, I had a taste on't.
sp.stage: To the bright Andromeda, chief chambermaid to the knight of the sun, at the sign of Scorpio, in the middle region, sent by the bellows-mender of Aeolus. Pay the post.
sp.l: This is stark madness.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Now mark the inside.
sp.p: Sweet lady, having now cast off this counterfeit cover of a madman, I appear to your best judgement a true and faithful lover of your beauty.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: He is mad still.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: If any fault you find, chide those perfections in you, which have have made me imperfect; 'tis the same sun that causeth to grow, and enforceth to wither.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: O rogue!

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Shapes and transhapes, destroys and builds again, I come in winter to you dismantled of my proper ornaments, by the sweet splendour of your cheerful smiles, I spring and live a lover.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Mad rascal still.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p: Tread him not under foot, that shall appear an honour to your bounties. I remain — mad till I speak with you, from whom I expect my cure. Yours all, or one beside himself, Franciscus.

sp.speaker: Lol:
sp.p: You are like to have a fine time on't, my master and I may give over our professions, I do not think but you can cure fools and madmen faster than we, with little pains too.

sp.speaker: Isa:
sp.p: Very likely.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: One thing I must tell you mistress, you perceive, that I am privy to your skill, if I find you minister once and set up the trade, I put in for my thirds, I shall be mad or fool else.

sp.speaker: Isa:
sp.l: The first place is thine, believe it, Lollio,
If I do fall.

sp.speaker: Lol:
sp.l: I fall upon you.

sp.speaker: Isa:
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Lol:
sp.l: Well I stand to my venture.

sp.speaker: Isa:
sp.l: But thy council now, how shall I deal with they:

sp.speaker: Lol:
sp.l: We do you mean to deal with 'em.

sp.speaker: Isa:
sp.l: Nay, the fair understanding, how to use 'em.

sp.speaker: Lol:
sp.p: Abuse they, that's the way to mad the fool, and make a fool of the madman, and than you use they kindly.

sp.speaker: Isa:
sp.l: 'Tis easy, I'll practise, do thou observe it,
The key of thy wardrobe.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: There fit yourself for they, and I'll fit they both for you.

sp.speaker: Isa:
sp.l: Take thou no further notice, than the outside.

sp.speaker: Lol:
sp.l: Not an inch, I'll put you to the inside.

sp.speaker: Ali:
sp.l: Lollio, art there, will all be perfect think'st thou
Tomorrow night, as if to close up the solemnity:
Vermandero expects us:

sp.speaker: Lol:
sp.l: I mistrust the madmen most, the fools will do well enough ▪
I have taken pains with them.

sp.speaker: Ali ▪
sp.l: Tush they cannot miss; the more absurdity,
The more commends it, so no rough behaviours
Affright the ladies; they are nice things thou knowest.

sp.speaker: Lol:
sp.p: You need not fear, sir, so long as we are there with our commanding peesles, they'll be as tame as the ladies themselves.

sp.speaker: Ali:
sp.p: I will see them once more rehearse before they go.

sp.speaker: Lol:
sp.p: I was about it, sir; look you to the madmen's morris, and let me alone with the other; there is one or two that I mistrust their fooling; I'll instruct them, and then they shall rehearse the whole measure.

sp.speaker: Ali:
sp.l: Do so, I'll see the music prepared: but, Lollio.
By the way, how does my wife brook her restraint:
does she not grudge at it.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: So, so, she takes some pleasure in the house, she would abroad else, you must allow her a little more length, she's kept too short.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.l: She shall along to Vermandero's with us,
That will serve her for a month's liberty.

sp.speaker: Lol:
sp.l: What's that on your face, sir?

sp.speaker: Ali:
sp.l: Where, Lollio, I see nothing.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Cry you mercy, sir, 'tis your nose, it showed like the trunk of a young elephant.

sp.speaker: Ali:
sp.l: Away, rascal: I'll prepare the music, Lollio

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Do, sir; and I'll dance the whilst; Tony, where art thou Tony?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Here, cousin, where art thou?

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Come, Tony, the footmanship I taught you.

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: I had rather ride, cousin.

sp.speaker: Lol:
sp.l: Ay, a whip take you; but I'll keep you out,
Vault in; look you, Tony, fa, la la la la.

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: Fa, la la la la.

sp.speaker: Lol:
sp.l: There, an honour.

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: Is this an honour, coz?

sp.speaker: Lol:
sp.l: Yes, and it please your worship.

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: Does honour bend in the hams, coz?

sp.speaker: Lol:
sp.l: Marry does it, as low as worship, squireship, nay yeomanry
Itself sometimes, from whence it first stiffened,
There rise a caper.

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: Caper after an honour, coz.

sp.speaker: Lol:
sp.l: Very proper, for honour is but a caper, rise as fast and high,
Has a knee or two, and falls to th' ground again,
You can remember your figure, Tony?

sp.speaker: Ant:
sp.l: Yes, cousin, when I see thy figure, I can remember mine.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Hey, how she treads the air, shough shough, tother way,
He burns his wings else, here's wax enough below Icarus,
More than will be cancelled these eighteen moons;
He's down, he's down, what a terrible fall he had, stand up,
Thou son of Cretan Dedalus, and let us tread the lower
Labyrinth; I'll bring thee to the clue.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Prithee, coz let me alone.

sp.speaker: Isa:
sp.l: Art thou not drowned,
About thy head I saw a heap of clouds
wrapped like a Turkish turban on thy back,
A crooked chameleon coloured rainbow hung,
Like a tiara down unto thy hams.
Let me suck out those billows in thy belly,
Hark how they roar and rumble in the streets.
Bless thee from the pirates.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Pox upon you, let me alone.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Why shouldst thou mount so high as Mercury,
Unless thou hadst reversion of his place?
Stay in the moon with me Endymion,
And we will rule these wild rebellious waves,
That would have drowned my love.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll kick thee if again thou touch me,
Thou wild unshapen antic; I am no fool,
You bedlam.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: But you are as sure as I am, mad.
Have I put on this habit of a frantic,
With love as full of fury to beguile
The nimble eye of watchful jealousy,
And am I thus rewarded?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ha dearest beauty.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: No, I have no beauty now,
Nor never had, but what was in my garments.
You a quick-sighted lover, come not near me.
Keep your caparisons, you're aptly clad,
I came a feigner to return stark mad.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Stay, or I shall change condition,
And become as you are.

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.l: Why Tony, whither now? why fool?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Whose fool, usher of idiots, you coxcomb.
I have fooled too much.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: You were best be mad another while then.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: So I am, stark mad, I have cause enough,
And I could throw the full effects on thee,
And beat thee like a fury.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p:
Do not, do not, I shall not forbear the gentleman under the fool, if you do; alas, I saw through your fox-skin before now: come, I can give you comfort, my mistress loves you, and
there is as arrant a madman i'th house, as you are a fool; your rival, whom she loves not; if after the mask we can rid her of him, you earn her love she says, and the fool shall ride her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: May I believe thee?

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Yes, or you may choose whether you will or no.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She's eased of him, I have a good quarrel on't.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Well, keep your old station yet, and be quiet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Tell her I will deserve her love.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: And you are like to have your desire.

sp.speaker: Fran:
sp.l: Down, down, down down down, and then with a horse trick,
To kick Latona's forehead, and break her bowstring.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: This is tother counterfeit, I'll put him out of his humour,
Sweet lady, having now cast this counterfeit cover of a madman.
I appear to your best judgement a true and faithful lover of your
Beauty. This is pretty well for a madman.

sp.speaker: Fran:
sp.l: Ha! what's that?

sp.speaker: Lol:
sp.l: Chide those perfections in you which made me imperfect.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I am discovered to the fool.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: I hope to discover the fool in you, ere I have done with you. Yours all, or one beside himself, Franciscus. This madman will mend sure.

sp.speaker: Fran:
sp.l: What? Do you read sirrah?

sp.speaker: Lol:
sp.p: Your destiny sir, you'll be hanged for this trick, and another that I know.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Art thou of counsel with thy mistress?

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Next her apron strings.

sp.speaker: Fran:
sp.l: Give me thy hand.

sp.speaker: Lol:
sp.p: Stay, let me put yours in my pocket first: your hand is true, is it not? It will not pick, I partly fear it, because I think it does lie.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Not in a syllable.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: So, if you love my mistress so well as you have handled the matter here, you are like to be cured of your madness.

sp.speaker: Fran:
sp.l: And none but she can cure it.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Well, I'll give you over then, and she shall cast your water next.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Take for thy pains past.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: I shall deserve more, sir, I hope, my mistress loves you, but must have some proof of your love to her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: There I meet my wishes.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: That will not serve, you must meet her enemy and yours.

sp.speaker: Fran:
sp.l: He's dead already.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Will you tell me that, and I parted but now with him?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Show me the man.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: I that's a right course now, see him before you kill him in any case, and yet it needs not go so far neither; 'tis but a fool that haunts the house, and my mistress in the shape of an idiot, bang but his fool's coat well-favouredly, and 'tis well.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Soundly, soundly.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.p: Only reserve him till the mask be passed; and if you find him not now in the dance yourself, I'll show you.
sp.l: In — in my master.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: He handles him like a feather. Hey!

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: Well said, in a readiness Lollio.

sp.speaker: Lol.
sp.l: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: Away then, and guide them in Lollio,
Entreat your mistress to see this sight.
Hark is there not one incurable fool
That might be begged? I have friends.

sp.speaker: Loll.
sp.l: I have him for you, one that shall deserve it too.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: Good boy Lollio.
'Tis perfect well fit, but once these strains,
We shall have coin and credit for our pains.

div.head: Actus quintus.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: One struck, and yet she lies by't — o my fears,
This strumpet serves her own ends, 'tis apparent now,
devours the pleasure with a greedy appetite,
And never minds my honour or my peace,
Makes havoc of my right; but she pays dear for't,
No trusting of her life with such a secret,
That cannot rule her blood, to keep her promise.
Beside, I have some suspicion of her faith to me,
Because I was suspected of my lord,
And it must come from her — hark by my horrors,
Another clock strikes two.

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: Pist, where are you?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Deflores!

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: I — is she not come from him yet?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: As I am a living soul not.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Sure the devil
Hath sowed his itch within her, who'd trust a waiting-woman?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I must trust somebody .

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Push, they are tarmagants.
Especially when they fall upon their masters
And have their ladies' first fruits, they're mad whelps,
You cannot stave 'em off from game royal, than
You are so harsh and hardy ask no counsel
And I could have helped you to a apothecary's daughter
Would have fallen off before eleven, and thank you too.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: O me, not yet, this whore forgets herself

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: The rascal fares so well, look you're undone,
The daystar by this hand, see Bosphorus plain yonder.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Advise me now to fall upon some ruin,
There is no counsel safe else.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Peace, I have't now,
For we must force a rising, there's no remedy.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: How? take heed of that.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Tush, be you quiet, or else give over all.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Prithee I ha'done than.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: This is my reach, I'll set some part afire of Diaphanta's chamber .

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: How? fire sir, that may endanger the whole house.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: You talk of danger when your same's on fire.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: That's true, do what thou wilt now.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Push, I aim at a most rich success, strikes all dead sure,
the chimney being a fire, and some light parcels
Of the least danger in her chamber only,
If Diaphanta should be met by chance then,
Far from her lodging, which is now suspicious,
It would be thought her fears and affrights then,
Drove her to seek for succour, if not seen
Or met at all, as that's the likeliest,
For her own shame she'll hasten towards her lodging,
I will be ready with a piece high-charged,
As 'twere to cleanse the chimney: there 'tis proper now,
But she shall be the mark.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: I'm forced to love thee now,
'Cause thou providest so carefully for my honour.

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: 'Slid it concerns the safety of us both,
Our pleasure and continuance.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: One word now prithee, how for the servants?

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: I'll dispatch them some one way, some another in the hurry,
For buckets, hooks, ladders; fear not you;
The deed shall find it's time, and I've thought since
Upon a safe conveyance for the body too.
How this fire purifies wit! Watch you your minute.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Fear keeps my soul upon't, I cannot stray from't.

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: Ha! what art thou that takest away the light
Betwixt that star and me? I dread thee not,
'Twas but a mist of conscience — all's clear again.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: Who's that, Deflores? Bless me! it slides by,
Some ill thing haunts the house, t'has left behind it,
A shivering sweat upon me; I'm afraid now.
This night hath been so tedious; o this strumpet!
Had she a thousand lives, he should not leave her
Till he had destroyed the last — list o my terrors,
Three struck by saint Sebastian's.

sp.speaker: Within:
sp.l: Fire, fire, fire.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: Already! How rare is that man's speed!
How heartily he serves me! his face loathes one,
But look upon his care, who would not love him?
The East is not more beauteous than his service.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Fire, fire, fire.

div.stage: Enter Deflores servants: pass over, ring a bell.

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: Away, dispatch, hooks, buckets, ladders; that's well said,
The fire bell rings, the chimney works, my charge;
The piece is ready,

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: Here's a man worth loving — o you're a jewel.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: Pardon frailty, madam,
In troth I was so well, I e'en forgotten myself.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: You've made trim work.

sp.speaker: Dia:
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: Hie quickly to your chamber, your reward follows you.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.l: I never made so sweet a bargain.

sp.speaker: Als:
sp.l: O my dear Joanna,
Alas, art thou risen too, I was coming,
My absolute treasure.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: When I missed you, I could not choose but follow.

sp.speaker: Als:
sp.l: Thou'rt all sweetness, the fire is not so dangerous.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: Think you so sir?

sp.speaker: Als:
sp.l: I prithee tremble not ▪ believe me 'tis not.

sp.speaker: Ver:
sp.l: O bless my house and me.

sp.speaker: Als:
sp.l: My lord your father.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Knave, whither goes that piece?

sp.speaker: Def:
sp.l: To scour the chimney,

sp.speaker: Ver:
sp.l: O well said, well said,
That fellow's good on all occasions.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: A wondrous necessary man, my lord.

sp.speaker: Ver:
sp.l: He hath a ready wit, he's worth 'em all, sir,
Dog at a house of fire, I ha' seen him singed ere now:
Ha, there he goes.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Als:
sp.l: Come sweet to bed now; alas, thou wilt get cold.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: Alas, the fear keeps that out;
My heart will find no quiet till I hear
How Diaphanta my poor woman fares;
It is her chamber sir, her lodging chamber.

sp.speaker: Ver:
sp.l: How should the fire come there?

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: As good a soul as ever lady countenanced,
But in her chamber negligent and heavy.
She 'scaped a mine twice.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Twice?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Strangely twice, sir.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Those sleepy sluts are dangerous in a house,
And they be never so good.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: O poor virginity! thou hast paid dear for't.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Bless us! What's that?

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: A thing you all knew once, diaphanta's burned.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: My woman, o my woman!

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Now the flames are
Greedy of her, burned, burned, burned to death sir.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: O my presaging soul!

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Not a tear more, I charge you by the last embrace
I gave you in bed before this raised us.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Now you tie me,
Were it my sister now she gets no more.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: All danger's passed, you may now take your rests, my lords,
The fire is thoroughly quenched; ah poor gentlewoman,
How soon was she stifled!

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Deflores, what is left of her inter,
And we as mourners all will follow her:
I will entreat that honour to my servant,
E'en of my lord himself.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Command it sweetness.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Which of you spied the fire first?

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: 'Twas I, madam.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: And took such pains in't too? A double goodness!
'Twere well he were rewarded.

sp.speaker: Ver:
sp.l: He shall be, Deflores, call upon me.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: And upon me, sir.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Rewarded? precious, here's a trick beyond me;
I see in all bouts both of sport and wit,
Always a woman strives for the last hit:

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I cannot taste the benefits of life
With the same relish I was wont to do.
Man I grow weary of, and hold his fellowship
A treacherous bloody friendship, and because
I am ignorant in whom my wrath should settle,
I must think all men villains; and the next
I meet, who ere he be, the murderer
Of my most worthy brother — ha! what's he?
sp.stage: Enter Deflores, passes over the stage.
sp.l: O the fellow that some call honest Deflores;
But methinks honesty was hard bested
To come there for a lodging, as if a Queen
Should make her palace of a pest-house,
I find a contrariety in nature
Betwixt that face and me, the least occasion
Would give me game upon him; yet he's so foul
One would scarce touch with a sword he loved,
And made account of, so most deadly venomous,
He would go never to poison any weapon
That should draw blood on him, one must resolve
Never to use that sword again in fight.
In way of honest manhood, that strikes him;
Some river must devour't, 'twere not fit
That any man should find it. — what again?
He walks a purpose by, sure to choke me up,
To infect my blood.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: My worthy noble lord.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Dost offer to come near and breath upon me?

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: A blow.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Yea, are you so prepared?
I'll rather like a soldier die by th'sword
Then like a politician by thy poison.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Hold, my lord, as you are honourable.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: All slaves that kill by poison, are still cowards.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: I cannot strike, I see his brother's wounds
Fresh bleeding in his eye, as in a crystal,
I will not question this, I know you're noble.
I take my injury with thanks given, sir.
Like a wise lawyer; and as a favour,
Will wear it for the worthy hand that gave it:
why this from him, that yesterday appeared,
So strangely loving to me?
O but instinct is of a subtler strain,
Guilt must not walk so near his lodge again,
He came never me now.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: All league with mankind I renounce for ever,
Till I find this murderer; not so much
As common courtesy, but I'll lock up:
For in the state of ignorance I live in,
A brother may salute his brother's murderer.
And wish good speed to'th villain in a greeting.

sp.speaker: Ver:
sp.l: Noble Piracquo.

sp.speaker: Tho:
sp.l: Pray keep on your way, sir,
I've nothing to say to you.

sp.speaker: Ver:
sp.l: Comforts bless you sir.

sp.speaker: Tho:
sp.l: I have forsworn compliment, in troth I have, sir;
As you are merely man, I have not left
A good wish for you, nor any here.

sp.speaker: Ver:
sp.l: Unless you be so far in love with grief,
You will not part from't upon any terms,
We bring that news will make a welcome for us.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: What news can that be?

sp.speaker: Ver:
sp.l: Throw no scornful smile
Upon the zeal I bring you, 'tis worth more sir,
Two of the chiefest men I kept about me,
I hide not from the law, or your just vengeance.

sp.speaker: Tho:
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: To give your peace more ample satisfaction,
Thank these discoverers.

sp.speaker: Tho:
sp.l: If you bring that calm,
Name but the manner I shall ask forgiveness in
For that contemptuous smile upon you:
I'll perfect it with reverence that belongs
Unto a sacred altar.

sp.speaker: Ver:
sp.l: Good sir rise,
Why now you overdo as much a this hand,
As you fell short of tother. Speak Alibius;

sp.speaker: Ali:
sp.l: 'Twas my wife's fortune, as she is most lucky
at a discovery to find out lately
Within our hospital of fools and madmen,
Two counterfeits slipped into these disguises;
Their names Franciscus and Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ver:
sp.l: Both mine sir, and I ask no favour for 'em.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: Now that which draws suspicion to their habits,
The time of their disguisings agrees justly
With the day of the murder.

sp.speaker: Tho:
sp.l: O blessed revelation!

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Nay more, nay more sir, I'll not spare mine own
In way of justice; they both feigned a journey
To Bramata, and so wrought out their leaves,
My love was so abused in't.

sp.speaker: Tho:
sp.l: Time's too precious
To run in waste now; you have brought a peace
The riches of five kingdoms could not purchase,
Be my most happy conduct, I thirst for 'em,
Like subtle lightning will I wind about 'em,
And melt their marrow in 'em.

sp.speaker: Jas:
sp.l: Your confidence I'm sure, is now of proof.
The prospect from the garden has showed
Enough for deep suspicion.

sp.speaker: Als:
sp.l: The black mask
That so continually was worn upon't,
Condemns the face for ugly ere't be seen,
Her despite to him, and so seeming bottomless.

sp.speaker: Jas.
sp.l: Touch it home then, 'tis not a shallow probe
Can search this ulcer soundly, I fear you'll find it
Full of corruption, 'tis fit I leave you,
She meets you opportunely from that walk
She took the back door at his parting with her.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Did my fate wait for this unhappy stroke
At my first sight of woman? — she's here.

sp.speaker: Bea:
sp.l: Alsemero!

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: How do you?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: How do I? Alas! how do you? you look not well.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: You read me well enough, I am not well.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Not well sir? Is't in my power to better you?

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Nay, then you're cured again.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Pray resolve me one question, lady.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: If I can.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: None can so sure. Are you honest?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, that's a broad question, my lord,

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: But that's not a modest answer, my lady:
Do you laugh? My doubts are strong upon me

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: 'Tis innocence that smiles, and no rough brow
Can take away the dimple in her cheek.
Say I should strain a tear to fill the vault,
Which would you give the better faith to?

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: 'Twere but hypocrisy of a sadder colour,
But the same stuff, neither your smiles nor tears
Shall move or flatter me from my belief,
You are a whore.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: What a horrid sound it hath!
It blasts a beauty to deformity;
Upon what face soever that breath falls,
It strikes it ugly: o you have ruined
What you can never repair again.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: I'll all demolish and seek out truth within you,
If there be any left, let your sweet tongue,
Prevent your hearts rifling; there I'll ransack
And tear out my suspicion.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: You may sir, 'tis an easy passage, yet if you please.
Show me the ground whereon you lost your love.
My spotless virtue may but tread on that
Before I perish.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Unanswerable,
A ground you cannot stand on, you fall down
Beneath all grace and goodness, when you set
Your ticklish heel on't; there was a vizor
O'er that cunning face, and that became you,
Now impudence in triumph rides upon't;
How comes this tender reconcilement else
Betwixt you and your despite, your rancorous loathing
Deflores? He that your eye was sore at sight of,
He's now become your arms supporter, your lips saint.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Is there the cause?

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Worse, your lust's devil, your adultery.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Would any but yourself say that,
'Twould turn him to a villain.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: 'Twas witnessed by the counsel of your bosom Diaphanta.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Is your witness dead then?

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: 'Tis to be feared,
It was the wages of her knowledge, poor soul,
She lived not long after the discovery.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Then hear a story of not much less horror,
Than this your false suspicion is beguiled with,
To your bed's scandal, I stand up innocence,
Which even the guilt of one black other deed,
Will stand for proof of, your love has made me
A cruel murderess:

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: A bloody one.
I have kissed poison for't, stroked a serpent,
That thing of hate, worthy in my esteem,
Of no better employment, and him most worthy
To be so employed; I caused to murder
That innocent Piracquo, having no
Better means than that worst, to assure
Yourself to me.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: O the place itself ere since
Has crying been for vengeance, the temple
Where blood and beauty first unlawfully
Fired their devotion, and quenched the right one,
'Twas in my fears at first, 'twill have it now,
O thou art all deformed.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Forget not sir,
It (For your sake) was done, shall greater dangers
Make the less welcome?

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: O thou shouldst have gone
A thousand leagues about to have avoided
This dangerous bridge of blood, here we are lost.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Remember I am true unto your bed.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: The bed itself's a charnel, the sheets shrowds
For murdered carcases, it must ask pause
What I must do in this, mean time you shall
be my prisoner only, enter my closet.
I'll be your keeper yet; o in what part
Of this sad story shall I first begin? — ha
This same fellow has put me in — Deflores.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Noble Alsemero!

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: I can tell you news sir, my wife has her commended to you

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: That's news indeed my lord ▪ I think she would
Commend me to the gallows if she could,
She ever loved me so well, I thank her.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: What's this blood upon your band Deflores?

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Blood? No sure, 'twas washed since.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Since when man?

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Since tother day I got a knock
In a sword and dagger school; I think 'tis out.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Yes, 'tis almost out, but 'tis perceived though.
I had forgotten my message; this it is,
What price goes murder?

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: How sir?

sp.speaker: Als:
sp.l: I ask you sir,
My wife's behind hand with you, she tells me,
For a brave bloody blow you gave for her sake
Upon Piracquo.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Upon? 'twas quite through him sure,
Has she confessed it?

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: As sure as death to both of you,
And much more than that:

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: It could not be much more,
'Twas but one thing, and that she's a whore.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: I could not choose but follow, o cunning devils!
How should blind men know you from fair faced saints?

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: He lies, the villain does belie me.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Let me go to her, sir.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Nay, you shall to her.
Peace crying crocodile, your sounds are heard,
Take your prey to you, get you into her sir.
I'll be your pander now, rehearse again
Your scene of lust, that you may be perfect
When you shall come to act it to the black audience
Where howls and gnashings shall be music to you.
Clip your adulteress freely, 'tis the pilot
Will guide you to the mare mortuum,
Where you shall sink to fathoms bottomless.

div.stage: Enter Vermandero, Alibius, Isabella, Thomazo, Franciscus, and Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: O Alsemero. I have a wonder for you

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: No sir, 'tis I, I have a wonder for you

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I have suspicion near as proof itself
For Piracquo's murder.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Sir, I have proof
Beyond suspicion, for Piracquo's muder.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Beseech you hear me, these two have been disguised
E'er since the deed was done.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: I have two other
That were more close dsguised then your two could be,
E'er since the deed was done.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: You'll hear me, these mine own servants.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Hear me, those nearer than your servants
That shall acquit them, and prove them guiltless.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: That may be done with easy truth, sir:

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: How is my cause bandied through your delays!
'Tis urgent in blood, and calls for haste;
Give me a brother alive or dead;
Alive, a wife with him, if dead for both.
A recompense for murder and adultery.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: O, o, o.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Hark, 'tis coming to you.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Nay, I'll along for company.

sp.speaker: Bea
sp.l: O, o.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: What horrid sounds are these?

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Come forth you twins of mischief.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Here we are, if you have any more
To say to us, speak quickly, I shall not,
Give you the hearing else, I am so stout yet,
And so I think that broken rib of mankind.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: An host of enemies entered my citadel,
Could not amaze like this, Joanna, Beatrice, Joanna.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: O come not near me sir, I shall defile you,
I am that of your blood was taken from you
For your better health, look no more upon't,
But cast it to the ground regardlessly,
Let the common shower take it, from distinction,
Beneath the stars, upon yond meteor
Ever hang my fate, amongst things corruptible,
I never could pluck it from him, my loathing
Was prophet to the rest, but never believed
Mine honour fell with him, and now my life.

sp.speaker: Alsemero,
sp.l: I am a stranger to your bed,
Your bed was cozened on the nuptial night,
For which your false-bride died.

sp.speaker: Als:
sp.l: Diaphanta!

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Yes, and the while I coupled with your mate
At barleybreak; now we are left in hell.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: We are all there, it circumscribes here.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: I loved this woman in spite of her heart,
Her love I earned out of Piraequo's murder.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Ha, my brother's murderer.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: Yes, and her honour's prize
Was my reward, I thank life for nothing
But that pleasure, it was so sweet to me,
That I have drunk up all, left none behind
For any man to pledge me.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Horrid villain!
Keep life in him for further tortures.

sp.speaker: Def.
sp.l: No, I can prevent you, here's my penknife still,
It is but one thread more, — and now 'tis cut.
Make haste Joanna by that token to thee.
Canst not forget so lately put in mind ▪
I would not go to leave thee far behind.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.l: Forgive me Alsemero, all forgive,
'Tis time to die, when 'tis a shame to live.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: O my name is entered now in that record,
Where till this fatal hour 'twas never read.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Let it be blotted out, let your heart lose it,
And it can never look you in the face,
Nor tell a tale behind the back of life,
To your dishonour, justice hath so right
The guilty hit, that innocence is quit
by proclamation, and may joy again.
Sir, you are sensible of what truth hath done,
'Tis the best comfort that your grief can find.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Sir, I am satisfied, my injuries
Lie dead before me, I can exact no more,
Unless my soul were loose, and could o'ertake
Those black fugitives, that are fled from thence
To take a second vengeance; but there are wraths
Deeper than mine ('tis to be feared) about 'em.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: What an opacous body had that moon:
That last changed on us? here's beauty changed
To ugly whoredom: here servant obedience
To a master-sin, imperious murder.
I a supposed husband changed embraces
With wantonness, but that was paid before;
Your change is come too, from an ignorant wrath
To knowing friendship. Are there any more on's?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes sir, I was changed too, from a little ass as I was, to a great fool as I am; and had like to ha' been changed to the gallows, but that you know my innocence always excuses me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I was changed from a little wit to be stark mad,
Almost for the same purpose.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Your change is still behind, but deserve best your transformation.
You are a jealous coxcomb, keep schools of folly,
And teach your scholars how to break your own head.

sp.speaker: Alib.
sp.l: I see all apparent wife, and will change now
Into a better husband, and never keep scholars
That shall be wiser than myself.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: Sir, you have yet a son's duty living,
Please you accept it, let that your sorrow
As it goes from your eye, go from your heart,
Man and his sorrow at the grave must part.

sp.speaker: Als.
sp.l: All we can do, to comfort one another,
To stay a brother's sorrow, for a brother;
To dry a child, from the kind father's eyes
Is to no purpose, it rather multiplies:
Your only smiles have power to cause relive
The dead again, or in their rooms to give
Brother a new brother, father a child;
If these appear, all griefs are reconciled.

div.head: Plays newly printed.
div.p: The wild-goose-chase, a comedy; written by Francis Beaumont and John Fletcher, gent '.
The widow, a comedy; written by Ben: Johnson, John Fletcher, and Thomas Midleton, gent '.

div.head: Plays in the press.
div.p: Five plays written by mr.James Shirley, being all of his that were acted at the Blackfriars: together with the court-secret, written by the same author, but never yet acted.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
